articles.title: About this site
articles.description: Some additional details about the website
articles.contents:
Why this site
A easy, fun, and informative way to share my research identity and academic notes
A way to reflect - on the practical side of my research, in particular
A way to interact - with researchers, educators, and all
Potential contributions to the educational research field in my home country
Notes for building a distill website
Disclaimer: this is NOT a tutorial and don’t use this if any of the following doesn’t make sense to you.
Things are not easy if you want use version control on a distill website. Many ways to do it but no easy ways. After multiple attempts, I figured out these steps working for my purpose:
Create a new repo on GitHub, don’t initiate anything, an empty repo will do (remember to copy the URL)
In RStudio IDE, create a new project, select distill blog/website (remember to check the configuration with github page), distill will create basic things you need for the web
How to push your local project to the existing repo? Well, use your terminal.
git init
git add .
git commit -m ‘First commit’
git remote add origin PUT THE URL HERE
git remote -v
git push origin master
Go to your GitHub repo to confirm whether the files are there.
Go back to your RStudio IDE, under the tools-version control-set up while noticing the URL is automatically copied there. Click Ok. Restart your RStudio IDE. Git is available now.
You think the Git function is working and you’re all good. No you are not. The pull and push buttons do not work.
git push -u origin master
YOU ARE NOW ALL SET.

articles.title: Claire Congli Zhang's Academic Website
articles.description: This is my personal academic website, where I update my CV and research projects and also host a research blog for Chinese K-12 educators.
articles.contents:
CONGLI (CLAIRE) ZHANG
Ph.D. Student
Educational Methodology, Policy, and Leadership, College of Education, University of Oregon
Address: 102J Lokey Education Bldg, 5267 University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403-5267
Email: congliz@uoregon.edu
Cell: 415-596-7343
Education Background
Ph.D. Quantitative Research Methods in Education, University of Oregon | Current
M.S. Organizational Leadership, Northeastern University | Mar 2018
B.S. Mathematics Education, Hebei Normal University, China | Jun 2001
Professional Experiences
Resident Fellow | EMPL, COE, UO | 2020-Current
Instructor/Teaching Assistant | EMPL, COE, UO | 2019-2020
• Instructor of record for two EMPL courses - EDLD 211 Exploring Leadership (CRN: 17306) and EDLD 313 Program Evaluation for Future Leaders (CRN: 36636) Responsible for all aspects of instructions
• Course developer for one EMPL course - EDLD 410 Team Building (CRN: 26809)
GE for Leadership and Community Engagement Initiatives | EMPL, COE, UO | 2018-2019
• Provide student leadership consultations at Holden Center and facilitate student leadership and community engagement programs and activities
• Teaching assistant for two EMPL courses – EDLD 311 Equity Leadership and Social Change (CRN: 27551) and EDLD 312 Effective Leadership Decision-Making (CRN: 35696)
Director of Education | NO.22 Middle School of Shijiazhuang | China | 2005-2016
• Head of the Education Department and Admission Office. Supervise and evaluate homeroom teachers. Responsible for student discipline throughout school and organization of all school events. Responsible for comprehensive student assessment. Collaborate with Parent Committee
• Lead of school educational research projects
Mathematics Teacher | NO.22 Middle School of Shijiazhuang | China | 1995-2016
• Teach Mathematics subject. Design curriculum and course materials
• Provide academic support to students individually or in groups
Research Projects
“Research on Construction of School-Guided Learning-Oriented Families” | 2011-2016
• Lead of a research team of 23 teachers on a five-year sub-project of a key research project “Research on the Framework of Combined Education by School, Home and Society” (ID: 01100255) managed by the China Youth & Children Research Center (CYCRC)
• Present findings on CYCRC national conference in May and November, 2012
• Awarded Distinguished Researcher by CYCRC on April, 2016
Publications & Conference Papers in U.S.
Porter, L. & Zhang, C. (2020, Apr 17-21) Pathways Through Which Principal Leadership Influences English Learner Outcomes: A Narrative Review and Theoretical Framework [Roundtable Session]. AERA Annual Meeting San Francisco, CA http://tinyurl.com/w2byc q2 (Conference Canceled)
